keyTakeAways: Sir Philip Pullman is urging the UK government to reform copyright laws to prevent AI companies from scraping writers' works without compensation.
Writers such as Kate Mosse and Richard Osman have raised concerns that AI training on literary content constitutes theft and harms creative industries.
Pullman argues that scraping literary works—such as his own—without payment is immoral and illegal, calling it a 'wicked system'.
The government launched a consultation in December 2024 on AI and copyright, receiving 11,500 responses, and has established expert working groups to address these issues.
Pullman emphasizes that imagination is a form of perception and is threatened by rigid education policies and the misuse of religion by institutions of power.
He insists that his work is not fantasy but a realistic exploration of the human condition through imaginative lenses, distinguishing himself from authors like JRR Tolkien.
The final book in his Lyra trilogy, The Rose Field, explores a realm of imagination—where ghosts, hopes, and memories exist only through imagination, reflecting on the value of creative perception.
Pullman is writing a memoir about his childhood and is considering the possibility of a future Lyra story, indicating ongoing engagement with his fictional universe.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sir Philip Pullman, renowned author of the His Dark Materials and The Book of Dust series, has urged the UK government to reform copyright laws to prevent AI companies from scraping literary works—such as his own—without compensation or recognition. He describes the practice as 'wicked' and immoral, arguing that it amounts to theft and threatens the future of creative industries. The issue follows a government consultation launched in December 2024, which received 11,500 responses and prompted the formation of expert working groups on AI and copyright. Pullman emphasizes the value of imagination, portraying it as a form of perception akin to emotional experiences like love, hope, and memory. He criticizes current education policies and religious institutions that suppress curiosity and creative thinking, aligning his personal narrative with broader societal concerns. The upcoming release of The Rose Field, the final book in the Lyra trilogy, reinforces his themes of imagination and resistance. Despite being a writer of imaginative fiction, Pullman insists his work is grounded in reality, not fantasy, and he remains open to the possibility of future stories in his universe.
title: Author Philip Pullman calls on government to act over 'wicked' AI scraping
